case_name: Dr. N. B. Khare v. Registrar of the Supreme Court

facts.text: Civil Miscellaneous Petition No. 915 of 1957 was filed in Original Jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: Civil Miscellaneous Petition No. 915 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal under Order V, rule 3 of the Supreme Court Rules

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under Order V, rule 3 of the Supreme Court Rules.

facts.text: V. S. Mani and Ganpat Rai appeared for the petitioner

anchor.surface_text: V. S. Mani and Ganpat Rai, for the petitioner.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on October 14, 1957 by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. October 14. The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.-

facts.text: Petition filed under Article 71(1) of the Constitution of India

anchor.surface_text: This is a petition under Art. 71 1  of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Election to the office of the President held on May 6 and Shri Rajendra Prasad declared elected

anchor.surface_text: On May 6, there was an election to the office of the President and Shri Rajendra Prasad was declared elected.

facts.text: Dr. N. B. Khare filed the petition as an intending candidate

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter Dr. N. B. Khare filed the present petition describing himself as an intending candidate

facts.text: Petitioner alleged violations of the provisions of the Constitution and that the election was invalid

anchor.surface_text: and alleging that there had been violations of the provisions of the Constitution and that the election was in companysequence number valid.

facts.text: Petition prayed for enquiry into grave doubts regarding Presidential election and to quash the proceedings as void

anchor.surface_text: The prayers in the petition are that grave doubts that exist in companynection with the Presidential election be enquired into, resolved and decided and the entire proceedings of the Presidential election be quashed as void .

facts.text: Registrar of the Supreme Court returned the petition for not conforming to Presidential and Vice-Presidential Elections Act, 1952 (Act XXXI of 1952) and Rules in O. XXXVII-A

anchor.surface_text: The Registrar of this Court returned the petition as number being in companyformity with the provisions of the Presidential and Vice-Presidential Elections Act, 1952  XXXI of 1952 , and as number satisfying the requirements of the Rules of this Court companytained in 0. XXXVII-A

facts.text: Section 14 of Act XXXI of 1952 requires election petition to be presented by candidate or ten or more electors

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 of Act XXXI of 1952 provides that numberelection shall be called in question except by an election petition presented to the Supreme Court in accordance with the provisions of the Act and of the Rules made by the Supreme Court under Art. 145 of the Constitution and it further provides that it should be presented by any candidate at such election or by ten or more electors.

facts.text: Rule 3 of O. XXXVII-A requires court-fee of Rs. 250

anchor.surface_text: The Rules framed by this Court with reference to this matter are companytained in 0. XXXVII-A. Rule 3 prescribes that a companyrt-fee of the value of Rs. 250 should be paid on the petition

facts.text: Rule 12 of O. XXXVII-A requires deposit of Rs. 2,000 as security for costs

anchor.surface_text: and r. 12 requires the petitioner to deposit a sum of Rs. 2,000 in cash as security for the payment of companyts that may become payable by him.

facts.text: Petitioner was not entitled to apply under Section 14 of the Act and petition defective under Rules 3 and 12

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is number a person entitled to apply under s. 14 of the Act and his petition was also defective as it did number companyply with the requirements of rr. 3 and 12.

facts.text: Petition was returned by the Registrar

anchor.surface_text: It was accordingly returned by the Registrar.

facts.text: Appeal brought against the Registrar's order

anchor.surface_text: Against that order, the present appeal has been brought.

facts.text: Petitioner contended that the petition is outside purview of Act XXXI of 1952 and O. XXXVII-A

anchor.surface_text: It is firstly companytended by Mr. Mani that the present petition is outside the purview of Act XXXI of 1952 and of XXXVII-A of the Supreme Court Rules.

facts.text: Petitioner argued Act XXXI of 1952 and Rules derogate from Supreme Court jurisdiction under Article 71(1)

anchor.surface_text: It is next companytended that the Act and the Rules in question are void on the ground that they derogate from the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court to enquire into and decide all disputes and doubts arising out of or in companynection with the election of the President or the Vice-President.

facts.text: Act XXXI of 1952 passed by Parliament under Article 71(3)

anchor.surface_text: Under Art. 71 3 , it is Parliament that is authorised It  make law for regulating any matter relating to or companynected with the election of the President or Vice President, and Act XXXI of 1952 has been passed by Parliament in accordance with this provision.

facts.text: Court held petitioner has no right to move for setting aside election except under Act XXXI of 1952

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner has, therefore, numberright to move for setting aside the election except in accordance with the provisions of Act XXXI of 1952.
This is a petition under Art. 71 1  of the Constitution of India.

issues.text: Whether the present petition is outside the purview of the Presidential and Vice-Presidential Elections Act, 1952 and Order XXXVII-A of the Supreme Court Rules because it raises doubts as to the validity of the election rather than disputes as to the election?

anchor.surface_text: Against that order, the present appeal has been brought. It is firstly contended by Mr. Mani that the present petition is outside the purview of Act XXXI of 1952 and of XXXVII-A of the Supreme Court Rules. It is argued that the Supreme Court is invested with jurisdiction to enquire into and decide all doubts and disputes arising out of or in connection with the election of the President, that Act XXXI of 1952 and O. XXXVII-A apply only when there is a dispute as to the election, but where the petition is founded upon doubts as to the validity of the election, it is number covered either by the Act or the Rules.

issues.text: Whether the Presidential and Vice-Presidential Elections Act, 1952 and the Rules in Order XXXVII-A are void as derogating from the jurisdiction conferred on the Supreme Court by Article 71(1) of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: It is next contended that the Act and the Rules in question are void on the ground that they derogate from the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court to enquire into and decide all disputes and doubts arising out of or in connection with the election of the President or the Vice-President. It is argued that under s. 18, the election could be set aside only on certain grounds and that further under clause b it could be done only if the result of the election is shown to have been materially affected, and that these are restrictions on the jurisdiction conferred by Art. 71 1 and are ultra vires.

issues.text: Whether the petitioner has a right as a citizen to approach the Supreme Court under Article 71(1) whenever an election has been held in breach of constitutional provisions, irrespective of the provisions of the Act?

anchor.surface_text: And finally it is contended that the petitioner has a right as a citizen to approach this Court under Art. 71 1 whenever an election has been held in breach of the constitutional provisions. For the reasons already given, this contention must fail. The right of a person to file an application for setting aside an election must be determined by the statute which gives it, and that statute is Act XXXI of 1952 passed under Art. 71 3 .

issues.text: Whether the petitioner is a 'candidate at such election' or otherwise entitled under section 14 of the Presidential and Vice-Presidential Elections Act, 1952 to present the election petition?

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is number a person entitled to apply under s. 14 of the Act and his petition was also defective as it did number comply with the requirements of rr. 3 and 12. It was accordingly returned by the Registrar.

arguments.claim: The present petition is outside the purview of Act XXXI of 1952 and O. XXXVII-A because it raises doubts as to the validity of the election rather than a dispute as to the election

anchor.surface_text: It is firstly contended by Mr. Mani that the present petition is outside the purview of Act XXXI of 1952 and of XXXVII-A of the Supreme Court Rules. It is argued that the Supreme Court is invested with jurisdiction to enquire into and decide all doubts and disputes arising out of or in connection with the election of the President,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the requirements of Act XXXI of 1952 and of the Rules in 0. XXXVII-A. It is next companytended that the Act and the Ru

arguments.court_reasoning: Any doubt concerning validity after election is held is ground for setting aside; substance of petition calls election in question requiring compliance with Act and Rules

arguments.claim: Act XXXI of 1952 and Rules in O. XXXVII-A are void as they derogate from Supreme Court jurisdiction under Art. 71(1) by imposing restrictions like those in s. 18

anchor.surface_text: It is next contended that the Act and the Rules in question are void on the ground that they derogate from the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court to enquire into and decide all disputes and doubts arising out of or in connection with the election of the President or the Vice-President. It is argued that under s. 18,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: th the election of the President and Vice-President would be enquired into. It does number prescribe the companyditions under which the petition for s

arguments.court_reasoning: Art. 71(1) only prescribes forum not conditions for petitions; Art. 71(3) empowers Parliament to regulate; Act validly passed thereunder

arguments.claim: Petitioner as citizen has right to approach Supreme Court under Art. 71(1) for elections in breach of constitutional provisions irrespective of Act

anchor.surface_text: And finally it is contended that the petitioner has a right as a citizen to approach this Court under Art. 71 1 whenever an election has been held in breach of the constitutional provisions.

arguments.court_reasoning: Right to challenge election conferred and conditioned only by statute Act XXXI of 1952 under Art. 71(3); no independent right

arguments.claim: Petitioner not entitled to present petition under s. 14 of Act XXXI of 1952 as not a candidate at the election or ten or more electors

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is not a person entitled to apply under s. 14 of the Act and his petition was also defective as it did not comply with the requirements of rr. 3 and 12.

arguments.claim: Petition defective for non-compliance with rr. 3 and 12 of O. XXXVII-A requiring court-fee and security deposit

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is not a person entitled to apply under s. 14 of the Act and his petition was also defective as it did not comply with the requirements of rr. 3 and 12. It was accordingly returned by the Registrar.

arguments.claim: Art. 71(1) merely prescribes Supreme Court as forum for election disputes/doubts; does not lay down conditions for petitions

anchor.surface_text: Article 71 1 merely prescribes the forum in which disputes in connection with the election of the President and Vice-President would be enquired into. It does not prescribe the conditions under which the petition for setting aside an election could be presented.

arguments.claim: Under Art. 71(3) Parliament authorised to regulate election matters including petition conditions; Act XXXI of 1952 valid

anchor.surface_text: Under Art. 71 3 , it is Parliament that is authorised to make law for regulating any matter relating to or connected with the election of the President or Vice President, and Act XXXI of 1952 has been passed by Parliament in accordance with this provision.

arguments.claim: Rights to challenge election are statutory not common law; enforceable only per statutory conditions

anchor.surface_text: The right to stand for election and the right to move for setting aside an election are not common law rights. They must be conferred by statute and can be enforced only in accordance with the conditions laid down therein.

holdings.text: The petitioner is not a person entitled to apply under s. 14 of the Act and his petition was also defective as it did not comply with the requirements of rr. 3 and 12.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is number a person entitled to apply under s. 14 of the Act and his petition was also defective as it did number companyply with the requirements of rr. 3 and 12.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner described as intending candidate, not candidate at election or ten or more electors as required by s.14; no court-fee or security deposited as per rr.3,12.

holdings.text: In substance the petition is one calling the election in question and it must satisfy the requirements of Act XXXI of 1952 and of the Rules in 0. XXXVII-A.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this contention. When once an election has been held, any doubt concerning its validity is material only as a ground for setting aside the election and that in fact is the prayer in the petition itself In substance the petition is one calling the election in question and it must satisfy the requirements of Act XXXI of 1952 and of the Rules in 0. XXXVII-A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Doubts as to validity after election held amount to grounds for setting aside election; prayer seeks to quash proceedings, thus within Act and Rules.

holdings.text: Article 71(1) merely prescribes the forum in which disputes in connection with the election of the President and Vice-President would be enquired into. It does not prescribe the conditions under which the petition for setting aside an election could be presented.

anchor.surface_text: Article 71 1  merely prescribes the forum in which disputes in companynection with the election of the President and Vice-President would be enquired into. It does number prescribe the companyditions under which the petition for setting aside an election companyld be presented.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of Art.71(1) limits it to forum; conditions regulated separately.

holdings.text: Under Art. 71(3), it is Parliament that is authorised to make law for regulating any matter relating to or connected with the election of the President or Vice President, and Act XXXI of 1952 has been passed by Parliament in accordance with this provision.

anchor.surface_text: Under Art. 71 3 , it is Parliament that is authorised It  make law for regulating any matter relating to or companynected with the election of the President or Vice President, and Act XXXI of 1952 has been passed by Parliament in accordance with this provision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.71(3) expressly empowers Parliament to legislate on election matters including petitions; Act validly enacted thereunder.

holdings.text: The contention that the Act and the Rules derogate from the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court under Art. 71(1) must accordingly be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention that the Act and the Rules derogate from the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court under Art. 71 1  must accordingly be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combining Arts.71(1)&(3), Act and Rules validly limit and regulate jurisdiction without derogation.

holdings.text: The petitioner has, therefore, no right to move for setting aside the election except in accordance with the provisions of Act XXXI of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner has, therefore, numberright to move for setting aside the election except in accordance with the provisions of Act XXXI of 1952.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No independent right under Art.71(1); must comply with statutory conditions.

holdings.text: The right to stand for election and the right to move for setting aside an election are not common law rights. They must be conferred by statute and can be enforced only in accordance with the conditions laid down therein.

anchor.surface_text: The right to stand for election and the right to move for setting aside an election are number companymon law rights. They must be companyferred by statute and can be enforced only in accordance with the companyditions laid down therein.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Election rights purely statutory; no common law or constitutional right apart from statute.

holdings.text: For the reasons already given, this contention must fail. The right of a person to file an application for setting aside an election must be determined by the statute which gives it, and that statute is Act XXXI of 1952 passed under Art. 71(3).

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons already given, this companytention must fail. The right of a person to file an application for setting aside an election must be determined by the statute which gives it, and that statute is Act XXXI of 1952 passed under Art. 71  3 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reiterates statutory exclusivity; citizen right claim rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention that the Act and the Rules derogate from the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court under Art. 71 1  must accordingly be rejected. The petitioner has, therefore, numberright to move for setting aside the election except in accordance with the provisions of Act XXXI of 1952. And finally it is companytended that the petitioner has a right as a citizen to approach this Court under Art. 71 1  whenever an election has been held in breach of the companystitutional provisions. For the reasons already given, this companytention must fail. The right of a person to file an application for setting aside an election must be determined by the statute which gives it, and that statute is Act XXXI of 1952 passed under Art. 71  3 . The petitioner must strictly bring himself within the four companyners of that statute and has numberrights apart from it.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; Registrar's return of petition upheld due to lack of locus standi under s.14 and non-compliance with rr.3 and 12 of O.XXXVII-A; all contentions rejected; Act XXXI of 1952 and Rules held valid

anchor.surface_text: Under Art. 71 3 , it is Parliament that is authorised It  make law for regulating any matter relating to or companynected with the election of the President or Vice President, and Act XXXI of 1952 has been passed by Parliament in accordance with this provision.

The petitioner has, therefore, numberright to move for setting aside the election except in accordance with the provisions of Act XXXI of 1952. For the reasons already given, this companytention must fail.
